entry.title: Bridging the gap with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper
entry.content:
With the extended maintenance end date rapidly approaching for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition releases 1503, 1603, 1709 - 1909, it is time for impacted customers to start planning their next steps before entering customer-specific maintenance on January 1, 2026.  

Mainstream maintenance, extended maintenance, and customer-specific maintenance are the three distinct maintenance phases applicable to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition under the SAP Maintenance Strategy.  

During mainstream maintenance, full support (SAP Notes, Support packages, Support package stacks, Feature package stacks, etc) is offered for a SAP product until a successor product is available. Extended maintenance offers similar support but requires a specific maintenance contract. For RISE customers, extended maintenance for S/4HANA Cloud private edition is covered by the regular annual subscription fee and does not require a specific maintenance addendum. Once extended maintenance ends, systems enter customer-specific maintenance (CSM), a phase with limited and restricted support services. Entering CSM as a RISE customer means the support and Service Level Agreement currently provided by SAP Enterprise Cloud Services will no longer be available.

 S/4HANA Maintenance Timelines   

  

To fully leverage the value of SAP, it's essential for customers to keep their S/4HANA release up to date - ensuring robust security, continuous innovation and optimal system performance. For this reason, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper service has been released to support RISE with SAP customers who have not yet upgraded to the latest S/4HANA Cloud, private edition version and are at risk of falling into customer-specific maintenance.  New customers who have not yet upgraded must upgrade before moving to RISE. Alternatively, they can move to RISE on their current S/4HANA release before entering customer-specific maintenance, as long as they also purchase the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper service. Customer-specific maintenance is not supported for new RISE customers. Safekeeper services are only applicable to S/4HANA Cloud releases, not SAP ERP.  

 

The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper service is purchased as a single sales SKU and includes:  

1) Upgrade Services  

A) SAP Cloud Application Services (CAS) for Release Version Upgrade  

OR  

B) SAP Cloud Application Services (CAS) for Regression Testing   

  

2) Infrastructure  

An additional non-productive sandbox tier is provided by SAP to match the size of the existing production system up to 6TiB.   

 

3) Maintenance-related services  

Your existing S/4HANA landscape entering customer-specific maintenance will continue to receive SAP Notes and corrections generally aligning with the scope of Extended Maintenance. It will mitigate the limitations of the customer-specific maintenance for the contracted period.   

 

Let’s look at two real-world scenarios.   

Example #1 In-Place Upgrade from S/4HANA 1809 to S/4HANA 2023

I'm a RISE with SAP customer running SAP S/4HANA release 1809 which will enter customer-specific maintenance on January 1st, 2026.   I want to upgrade my existing systems to SAP S/4HANA 2023.   

In this scenario, the customer purchases SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper at least 90 days prior to the safekeeper contract start date (Sept-30-2025) and opts for the upgrade service a) CAS for Release Version Upgrade. Customer has a production system RAM of 512GB.

As of January 1, 2026, the safekeeper service will be initiated. This includes:   

  •   Deployment of the sandbox infrastructure (copy of existing production system running S/4HANA 1809)    
  • Commencement of the CAS services  
  • SAP Notes and corrections on the existing S/4HANA 1809 landscape  

Following the infrastructure deployment, an upgrade planning workshop is scheduled with CAS delivery team to provide a detailed project plan. Any additional infrastructure for a parallel landscape (e.g. development/ testing) will need to be procured separately. SAP specialists guide, navigate, and support the upgrade/update process as a whole. On-going support is offered until the production go-live.   

Example Brownfield Scenario  

  

Further reading  
CAS for Release Version Upgrade Scope Document: https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center/agreements/services/scope-documents.html?sort=latest_desc&search=release%20version%20upgrade   

How to upgrade blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/upgrade-your-sap-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-following-sap-activate/ba-p/13956251   

 

#2 Greenfield/ Selective Data Transition  

I'm a RISE with SAP customer running SAP S/4HANA release 1909 entering customer-specific maintenance on January 1, 2026.  I do not want to upgrade my existing systems, but instead, implement a new installation of systems on a more current release.   

In this scenario, the suitable upgrade service is b) CAS for Regression Testing.   

As of January 1, 2026, the safekeeper service will be initiated. This includes:   

  •   Deployment of the sandbox infrastructure (empty greenfield system with the desired target release e.g. 2023)    
  • Commencement of the CAS package for Regression Testing  
  • SAP Notes and corrections on the existing S/4HANA 1909 landscape  

Implementing a greenfield S/4HANA deployment typically involves replicating or redesigning previous business processes or adopting SAP best practices. These processes can be tested and validated in the new sandbox environment before implementing in other tiers. Customer will need to procure additional systems (DEV, QAS and PRD) based on the project plan.

Example Greenfield Scenario  

  

Further reading  

Regression Testing Service Scope Document: https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center/agreements/services/scope-documents.html?sort=latest_desc&search=SAP%20Cloud%20Application%20services%20for%20regression%20testing   

  

As SAP S/4HANA 1503 and 1605 were built on an ECC solution stack, customers running these releases will require a system conversion to a more recent SAP S/4HANA release. In this scenario, CAS for Release Version Upgrade does not apply, and the CAS for Regression Testing will be offered.   

  

Contract Duration  

The minimum contract duration for Safekeeper is 12 months and the maximum is 27 months (or up to 48 months in case of releases 1503 & 1605). Customers are expected to have moved to a more current release within mainstream maintenance by the end of their contracted period. Extensions are available for customers who did not purchase the full term initially.  

 

Add-ons  

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper services are available for selected add-ons within the scope of RISE with SAP, as set forth in the list attached to the following SAP Note 3424346. This list will be expanded as new products are added, so it is recommended to check back frequently if you plan to use Safekeeper.   

  

Extract from the SAP S4HANA Cloud Safekeeper Add-on List  

 

The single source of truth for Safekeeper availability is the SAP Product Availability Matrix at https://support.sap.com/pam  

Please note that add-ons having a longer mainstream maintenance date than Safekeeper availability for the specific release will not be included in the list attached to the SAP note. However, such add-ons will still be covered by SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper services.   

  

Conclusion  

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper has been introduced to support RISE with SAP customers in their transition to a more current SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition release. By providing structured upgrade or reimplementation paths, enabled by SAP Cloud Application Services, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper bridges the gap between the end of extended maintenance and the adoption of a current S/4HANA release, helping RISE customers maintain their support and SLAs from the SAP Enterprise Cloud Services organization.

  

 

Acknowledgment to contributors/reviewers/advisors:

Aurelien Kuleczka, co-author, Cloud Architect & Advisor, Enterprise Cloud Services

Tara Gibney, co-author, Cloud Architect & Advisor, Enterprise Cloud Services

Saurabh Sharma, Cloud Architect & Advisor, Enterprise Cloud Services

Allan Hughes,  Cloud Architect & Advisor, Enterprise Cloud Services

Jurgen Pirotte, S/4HANA Centre of Excellence

Stefan Held, Cloud Architect & Advisor, Enterprise Cloud Services

Sara Dya, RISE with SAP Partner Business Development

entry.title: Re: S4 Manage Characteristic Catalogs for SUP
entry.content: Not sure on how the Manage Characteristic Catalogs app looks like but I feel, you can create a custom field using the Custom Fields and Logic app. Use business context like SD_SALES_DOCUMENT or SD_SALES_DOCUMENT_HEADER, Populate the custom field with the VBAK value you need via logic or enhancement, Then expose it in the Manage Characteristic Catalogs app. This workaround lets you use standard VBAK data indirectly, even if the field isn’t natively available.

entry.title: Re: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build – Part 4: Managing Access to Custom Joule Skills
entry.content:
Great post! thank you.

I have a question for you. 

I'm currently setting up Joule Studio in SAP BTP following your link, and I’ve encountered a scenario where it seems I need to create another formation, as one is already in use in my environment.

Could you please clarify the following:

  1. Does creating a new Joule formation require an additional license or subscription quota within my BTP global account?

  2. If I update or extend Joule capabilities in one formation, will the Joule instance connected to my existing SAP SuccessFactors tenant (in a different formation) automatically recognize the new skills I create in the Joule Studio, or are formations completely isolated in terms of skill visibility and system awareness?

Regards.

entry.title: Staff your SAP Cloud ERP Enterprise Projects with the right Employees
entry.content:
Effective project and resource management is crucial for companies to deliver successful projects. Organizations running Enterprise Projects and/or Customer Projects in SAP Cloud ERP have the possibility to leverage SAP Project and Resource Management to optimize the project success. Resource Management is a process which spans normally over the complete lifetime of a project, starting with the initial finding and assignment of people, doing the continuous staffing forecasts and handling conflicts like substituting people. This blog provides an overview of how SAP Project and Resource Management facilitates these different staffing capabilities during the project life cycle of Enterprise Projects in SAP Cloud ERP.

Introduction:

Enterprise projects in SAP Cloud ERP   can be used to manage different kinds of projects in different industries. Examples are:

    • Overhead projects: for example, administrative projects or projects for research and development,
    • Investment projects: for example, projects to develop or maintain physical assets,
    • Projects with revenue: for example, engineer-to-order projects,
    • Statistical projects: can be used for certain reporting needs, without carry actual costs itself

Details about the different Project Types are documented in the following blog:
The two project control possibilities in SAP S/4HA... - SAP Community

 

Optimizing Resource Allocation:

Even in a simple project scenario, where an enterprise project merely serves as a cost collector without a formal project structure, managing resources is still required. Team members can log hours against the project, so optimizing resource allocation is crucial. To do this, you need clear visibility of available and skilled resources

Resource Management capability of SAP Project and Resource Management covers the following key aspects:

  • Transparency: Overview of projects people are working on and identification of conflicts
  • Reduce time to staff for Projects:
    • Staffing: Find available and skilled people and staff persons as requested and consider their availability
    • AI-assisted skill matching: overcome challenges like outdated employee profiles and reviewing many profiles manually
  • Increase staffing accuracy: Project workers can directly maintain their forecasts based on when they are needed for a project
  • Increase time-booking quality: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Timesheet worklist includes projects on which person is staffed
  • Single source of truth: the close integration between resource management information with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Project data provides synchronized data
  • SAP unified User Experience
  • Simple to adapt 

 

Basic scenarios and concepts:

SAP Project and Resource Management is a SaaS offering on SAP Business Technology Platform. Once the subscription is in place a scope item facilitates the setup.

Users can choose if resource management apps for business users should directly run in the SAP Cloud ERP Launchpad, e.g. Project Managers using the Project-related apps can also directly see the resource management apps they need.

 

Setup:

To proceed with the setup the following sources contain more details.
Administration Guide:
https://help.sap.com/docs/PPRM_OD/542f4545bc9d4ecd80bc3a0a6913a735/434f2ec669444cc98583a1c4eadca05a.html

The blog “Setup Resource Management Capability in SAP Project and Resource Management” provides a summary how to proceed by setting up the integration:
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/setup-resource-management-capability-in-sap-projects-and-resource/ba-p/13999829

 

Process:

Harmonizing staffing with project setup and milestone planning can reduce Backoffice efforts and allow people to focus on what is needed to deliver projects successfully instead of spending effort in maintaining consistent information across different sources.  

The process starts in SAP Cloud ERP when a Resource demand is created:

 


Screen shows the resource demand defined in the Enterprise Project

Once the Enterprise Project Integration is setup for SAP Cloud ERP “human resource” demands create the Resource Requests in Resource Management.

The process is explained along the most used apps in this blog.

1. Manage Resource Requests (Role: Project Manager)

Resource Request contains the need for a specific resource and is normally being refined by a user, e.g. Project Manager. During the refinement information about needed skills, scope description, requested resource organization are added. Once the request is complete the Project Manager can “publish” the request, so it becomes visible to the Resource Managers. No need to send additional information via email and capture the information directly where it is needed.


Screen shows the resource request which was published and includes “SAP Cloud ERP” as a required skill

 

2. Staff Resource Requests (Role: Resource Manager)

Resource Managers review the request and start now with the search of candidates. Availability and Skill matching are performed and available candidates identified. Resource Manager can propose or directly staff one or multiple candidates:

  • Proposing a candidate, allows Project Manager to accept / decline candidates
  • Soft booking is not yet confirmed staffing and only visible in resource management, while Hard booking is a confirmed booking type and people will see staffing in the SAP Cloud ERP timesheet app.
  • Forward requests, in case no suitable candidates are identified a request can be forwarded to another organization

Learn more how the AI-Assisted Advanced Skill Matching facilitates the search of skilled candidates check:
Unlock Efficient Resource Management with AI in SA... - SAP Community


Screen shows the matching candidates list and the Advanced Skill Match for Lilian Blair – Lilian is being assigned by using the “Quick Assign” feature

 

3. Manage Resource Utilization (Role: Resource Manager)

Provides transparency how people are utilized, visualizes conflicts of over / under bookings and shows directly on which projects and roles people are working.

Resource Managers can also create, change and move assignments in order to resolve conflicts and adjust the planning.


Screen shows a list of filtered employees which includes Lilian Blair and her staffing for the Project Expert role

 

4. My Assignments (Role: Project Team Member)

Once employees are staffed and have the needed authorization, they can maintain a staffing forecast means they can adjust in which weeks they work how many hours on a project. This allows them to refine and balance between different project assignments and align their involvement along with the planned project milestones, considering planned absences etc.

The updated information is afterwards visible for Resource- and Project Managers to ensure everyone has the updated information.



Screen shows mobile view of Lilian’s “My Assignment” app.

Staffed hours and candidates will be visible in SAP Cloud ERP. The Enterprise Project demand will get directly information about the assigned people and hours. This helps to bring up staffing information in the employee’s timesheet worklist to simplify timesheet capturing and reduce the time to find the right project.

 

Summary:

Resources assignments and staffed hours are kept in synch between the SAP Cloud ERP and Resource Management, which ensures that all users have the same view on resource demands and what is being staffed.

SAP Project and Resource Management supports you by gaining transparency on your resource utilization situation with a fully integrated and embedded into the SAP User Experience scenario.

To learn more and to explore Resource Management in SAP Project and Resource Management you can find more information and access the free trial under:

https://www.sap.com/prm

 

Companies running Customer Projects in SAP Cloud ERP can also consult the following blog:
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/overcoming-challenges-in-staffing-customer-projects-with-sap-project-and/ba-p/13748436

entry.title: Exploring Innovation: Discover What's New in the SAP Utilities Community
entry.content:
Dear Utilities Community

I am delighted to announce that the July edition of the SAP Utilities newsletter is live!

 

Once again, we have exciting news to share about the utilities industry!

We find ourselves in an exciting phase of innovation. Read the update about our SAP Continuous Influence Session for SAP S/4HANA Utilities. As an SAP customer, you can submit improvement requests, vote on ideas from others, and collaborate with SAP experts to help develop forward-looking solutions.

The coming weeks are packed with events! First up is SAP for Utilities by ASUG happening from September 8-10 in Denver. Then we head to CHARGE Europe in Istanbul on October 13-14, 2025. Looking ahead, preparations are already underway for next year’s SAP for Energy and Utilities Conference, taking place from April 21-23, 2026 in the beautiful French city of Toulouse!

We’re also pleased to showcase customer success stories from around the world. Iberdrola is integrating AI in its daily operations to accelerate the energy transition. Salzburg AG adopted RISE with SAP for a unified, agile IT landscape. Hinduja Renewables is scaling with SAP Cloud ERP, while TEAG is advancing digitalization and decentralization with RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Badenova is transforming customer experience through sales automation with SAP Sales Cloud Version 2.

Curious to explore the full stories?  You can access the complete newsletter here. 

Looking to stay connected? We'd love to keep you updated with the latest news from the utilities industry. If you haven't received your copy yet, we invite you to sign up and sign up here.

entry.title: Re: Storage Location as MRP area
entry.content:
If the storage location is not there in PR, then, it could be due to the following reasons

  • If the sales order for the FG material doesn’t pass the storage location correctly to the raw material demand, the system defaults to plant-level planning. This often happens when the BOM or routing doesn’t specify the storage location for the component. So, if needed, check with PP team also on MRP related settings.
  • In MRP1, the MRP Area assignment must be active. In MRP4, check the Storage Location MRP Indicator—it should be set to 2 (Sloc-level planning). If this is missing, the system may revert to plant-level planning even during Sloc-level MRP runs.
  • If the special procurement key or source list doesn’t specify a storage location, the PR will be created without one—even if MRP was run at the Sloc level.

entry.title: Unable to see the log during Invoice cancellation
entry.content:

We have implemented a custom logic under the BADI (SD_BIL_FLEX_CANCELLATION ) for Invoice cancellation based on the staus of IRN,

the same thing we tried during Runtime during debugging we were able to see the Message Text "Invoice cannot be cancelled please cancel the IRN first" 

Attahced screenshot for your reference, community membrs need you support.

Regards

Sandeep Patel

entry.title: Prevent internal movement tasks from being created when a source bin already has tasks again it
entry.content:
Hi SAP,


Our warehouse team has inquired about a potential improvement opportunity that may help with accuracy and reduce human operator errors. 


The team would like to prevent internal movement tasks from being created when a source bin already has tasks again it, such as picking or putaway tasks.  We would still like to be able to create multiple picking and putaway tasks to the same location (source bin) but we wouldn’t want to be able to add internal movement tasks to a bin that is already a source bin for the other two types.


We would like to understand what is and isn’t possible with this.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Prevent internal movement tasks from being created wh...
entry.content:
Hi,

 

I don't see an option with standard way, but you may consider use below BADI to set the request quantity as 0 to prevent the WT creation.

BADI Definition /SCWM/EX4_CORE_RMS_QUANTITY

Description Change of Requested Quantity for Stock Removal

 

Best Regard,

entry.title: Looking for SAP FICO Project Work (Freelance/Low Cost/Even Free)
entry.content:
Hi everyone 👋,

I’m currently learning SAP FICO (S/4HANA) and truly want to get real-time project experience to apply what I’ve been upskills my self— whether it’s in support, configuration, testing, or documentation.

I’m open to:
Freelance or remote projects
Low budget or even unpaid work
Assisting any consultant, company, or team who needs support
Right now, gaining practical experience matters more to me than payment. I just want an opportunity to work, learn, and contribute.
If you have anything where I can support — even small tasks — I’d be really grateful.

Please feel free to message me or tag someone who might be looking for support in SAP FICO.

Thanks in advance for reading and supporting! 😊

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Finance

entry.title: Re: Unable to see the log during Invoice cancellation
entry.content:
Hi,

It seems you are encountering an issue with the custom logic implemented in the BADI SD_BIL_FLEX_CANCELLATION Sales - Flexible Billing Document Cancellation for invoice cancellation based on the IRN status. The error message ‘Invoice cannot be cancelled please cancel the IRN first’ is visible during debugging but not in the VF11 app, where you see a blank log screen.

You may try to add a message to log to help you better debugging. 

CLASS-METHODS log_message
IMPORTING
!iv_msgty TYPE symsgty
!iv_msgid TYPE symsgid
!iv_msgno TYPE symsgno
!iv_msgv1 TYPE any OPTIONAL
!iv_msgv2 TYPE any OPTIONAL
!iv_msgv3 TYPE any OPTIONAL
!iv_msgv4 TYPE any OPTIONAL.

METHOD log_message.
DATA: ls_message TYPE bapireturn.
ls_message-type = iv_msgty.
ls_message-id = iv_msgid.
ls_message-number = iv_msgno.
ls_message-message_v1 = iv_msgv1.
ls_message-message_v2 = iv_msgv2.
ls_message-message_v3 = iv_msgv3.
ls_message-message_v4 = iv_msgv4.
APPEND ls_message TO messages.
ENDMETHOD.

Best regards, Dequan Xu

entry.title: API to download attachments of Projects
entry.content:
Dear Team,

I am trying to download attachments of projects through API so I have enabled communication arrangement with scenario, SAP_COM_0308. But I don't understand how to use this API to get attachment. Can you please suggest us how to fulfill our requirement?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: API to download attachments of Projects
entry.content:
In the communication scenario Enterprise Project Integration (SAP_COM_0308), you can use the generic Attachments service (API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV) to manage attachments. Please follow below steps: 

1. Call GET method with operation GetAllOriginals to retrieve the metadata of the attachment associated with the project.

  • For enterprise project, use BusinessObjectTypeName = '/S4PPM/PRJ' and LinkedSAPObjectKey = '<UUID for project> or <UUID for WBS element>'
  • For professional services project, use BusinessObjectTypeName = '/CPD/EP' and LinkedSAPObjectKey = '<external ID for project>'
  • For professional services project element, use BusinessObjectTypeName = '/CPD/PFP' and LinkedSAPObjectKey = '<external ID for work package>'

Sample request URL for professional services work package:
GET <host>/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV/GetAllOriginals?BusinessObjectTypeName='/CPD/PFP'&LinkedSAPObjectKey='<external ID for work package> '

The following properties can be found in response body:
<d:DocumentInfoRecordDocType>xxx</d:DocumentInfoRecordDocType>
<d:DocumentInfoRecordDocNumber>xxxxxxxxx</d:DocumentInfoRecordDocNumber>
<d:DocumentInfoRecordDocVersion>xx</d:DocumentInfoRecordDocVersion>
<d:DocumentInfoRecordDocPart>xxx</d:DocumentInfoRecordDocPart>
<d:LogicalDocument>xxxxxxxxx</d:LogicalDocument>
<d:ArchiveDocumentID>xxxxxxxxx</d:ArchiveDocumentID>
<d:LinkedSAPObjectKey>xxxxxxxxx</d:LinkedSAPObjectKey>
<d:BusinessObjectTypeName>xxxxxxxxx</d:BusinessObjectTypeName>

2. Use the properties retrieved from step 1 to call GET method with entity AttachmentContentSet to download the attachment content.

Sample request URL:
GET <host>/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV/AttachmentContentSet(DocumentInfoRecordDocType='xxx',DocumentInfoRecordDocNumber='xxxxxxxxx',DocumentInfoRecordDocPart='xxx',DocumentInfoRecordDocVersion='xx',LogicalDocument='xxxxxxxxx',ArchiveDocumentID='xxxxxxxxx',LinkedSAPObjectKey='xxxxxxxxx',BusinessObjectTypeName='xxxxx')/$value

entry.title: Re: The E in Event-Driven Architecture: Introducing SAP’s new Event-Add for ERP
entry.content:
Hi @Cocquerel ,

currently the differences are in respect to connectivity (via AEM) and to pricing. In future the intention is to add features that would be unique to the Event Add-On.

In respect to the details of the pricing the SAP Discovery Center is the place. I assume you have looked up the number there, and this is what I would recommend. It seems in the right range.

Let me try to help you with a few statements though that will make it easier to put the pricing in context:

  • You do pay for activated AEM brokers - you do activate a broker for use with the add-on in AEM.
  • You can connect several backends with add-ons installed to an AEM broker (e.g. an ECC and an S/4HANA against a single broker)
  • There is no differentiation between productive, test or dev brokers. So dev or test brokers are not free of charge. As said, it is the activations on AEM brokers that count, not the number of installed add-ons.
  • The pricing is tiered as you can see in Discovery Center. 

Hope this helps for now. I understand that we need to provide reference architectures and pricing examples as part of this blog series.

Best,

Karsten

entry.title: Why SAP ISA-M Still Matters – A Strategic Foundation for Modern Integration
entry.content:
In the era of APIs, hybrid landscapes, and cloud-native development, it's easy to assume that methodologies like SAP ISA-M (Integration Solution Advisory Methodology) are outdated. But the truth is: ISA-M is more relevant than ever. It remains a strategic compass for defining and implementing integration architectures that are sustainable, business-aligned, and tool-agnostic.

 

🔍 What is SAP ISA-M?

SAP ISA-M is a structured methodology that helps enterprises define their integration strategy, classify integration use cases, and select the right technologies and governance models. It supports decision-making across cloud, hybrid, and on-premise landscapes – regardless of whether you’re using SAP Integration Suite, SAP Advanced Event Mesh, or third-party platforms.

🔑 Why ISA-M Still Matters Today

  1. Strategic Guidance for Cloud Transformation

ISA-M is widely used during S/4HANA and RISE with SAP transformations to assess legacy middleware (e.g., PI/PO) and design modern, API- and event-driven target architectures.

  1. Technology-Agnostic by Design

ISA-M is not tied to specific products. It provides a framework for integration strategy, which remains valid even as tools evolve – from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite and beyond.

  1. Use Case-Driven Approach

By analyzing integration needs across five integration styles (e.g., process integration, data integration, event-driven integration), ISA-M helps teams design purposeful and scalable architectures.

  1. Connecting Business and IT

The methodology fosters collaboration between business owners, architects, and integration teams – ensuring that integration becomes a business enabler, not just a technical necessity.

 

Where ISA-M is Used Today

✅ Cloud Transformations & RISE with SAP

✅ Modernization of Legacy Interfaces

✅ Enablement & Governance Models

It outlines the phases in a modernization journey—Review, Scope and Define Use Cases—and shows how to transition towards a future-ready, hybrid integration platform.

  • Assess Integration Strategy
  • Review Existing Integration Architecture
  • Scope and Define Best Practices and Target Architecture
  • Give power to the people

 

🚀 Outlook: What’s Next for ISA-M?

🔧 1. ISA-M in INTAS – SAP Integration Assessment Service

SAP’s INTAS (Integration Assessment Service) is a structured offering to help customers evaluate and modernize their integration landscape. ISA-M provides the core methodology behind this service:

  • Assessment of legacy and custom interfaces
  • Mapping use cases to modern SAP Integration Suite capabilities
  • Tailored modernization roadmap aligned to Clean Core principles

With INTAS, organizations benefit from a guided modernization plan that is both strategic and executable.

I will give you some more insights in on of our upcoming Integration Modernization expert sessions: https://events.sap.com/expertsession-isam/en_us/home.html

🔗 2. ISA-M and the SAP Integrated Toolchain

The SAP Integrated Toolchain for Modernization Projects combines multiple SAP tools and services, such as:

  • SAP Cloud ALM
  • SAP Signavio
  • SAP LeanIX
  • SAP WalkMe
  • SAP BTP ( with our focus on Integration Suite)

We us ISA-M acts as a strategic layer below the toolchain, ensuring that all activities – from modeling to implementation – follow a consistent integration strategy. For example:

  • LeanIX is the central tool for your overall Enterprise Architecture  → ISA-M will help to control technologies and applications along the concept and to establish a government model
  • Signavio is used to model business processes → ISA-M helps derive integration patterns
  • SAP Integration Suite itself can be used to integrate the toolchain (itself) → ISA-M ensures style and governance fit, e.g. usage of SAP Advanced Event Mesh in combination with LeanIX Webhooks.

ISA-M connects the dots, providing strategic continuity across the entire toolchain.

We are currently working out an Integration Modernization expert which will give the required insights how you can implement it. Stay tune and follow our journey here https://events.sap.com/eur-sap-integration-modernization-expert-sessions/en_us/home.html

You would like to practice (e.g. with Integration content)? Just let me know.

🧼  3. ISA-M and Clean Core

Clean Core is one of the key guiding principles in SAP’s modernization strategy. But a Clean Core isn’t just about avoiding modifications – it’s about separating business logic from system logic and creating modular, scalable architectures.

Here’s how ISA-M supports a Clean Core approach:

  • Recommends using APIs, events, and standardized integration styles
  • Avoids hard-coded dependencies between systems
  • Encourages centralized governance and reuse of services

By following ISA-M, companies are not just modernizing their interfaces – they are actively cleaning their core.

 We hosted a first session how ISA-M can help you to ensure a clean-core approach Find the recording here: https://dam.sap.com/mac/app/e/video/embed/vAemLss?ltr=a&rc=10&doi=SAP1206809&includeSapBrandedWraper=true&includeRelatedAssets=true

 

✅ Final Thoughts

Integration is no longer just a technical challenge – it’s a strategic business discipline. And while the tools and technologies evolve, the need for a methodical, business-aligned integration strategy remains constant.

That’s why ISA-M continues to be a critical success factor for integration modernization, clean core transformation, and cloud-centric architectures.

Whether you're just starting your transformation journey or reviewing an existing landscape, ISA-M gives you the structure, language, and clarity to do it right.

👉 Explore more:

  • ISA-M GitHub Repository
  • ISA-M Mission in SAP Discovery Center

 You need support? Send us a mail SAP Integration Modernization <integration.modernization@sap.com>

entry.title: Re: Seamless Planning with Datasphere & SAC: Seamless Planning in the Cloud?
entry.content:
Hi Dirk,

First of all, thank you very much for your detailed and insightful blog post on Seamless Planning with SAP Datasphere and SAC. It was incredibly helpful for my research and internal strategy discussions.

 I have a few follow-up questions regarding the future development of Seamless Planning in 2025 and 2026:

  1. What is SAP's roadmap for Seamless Planning in late 2025 and into 2026?
  2. To what extent will it be supported to build Seamless Planning models using existing data models with complex parent/child hierarchies and custom dimensions – even across multiple Datasphere spaces (cross-space modeling)?
  3. What role will the new Insight Apps with integrated planning capabilities play in this context?
    Will customers be able to extend or build their own Insight Apps for planning scenarios?

Your thoughts on these questions would be extremely valuable, especially as Seamless Planning seems to be evolving into the new architectural standard for enterprise planning.

Thanks again for sharing your expertise!

entry.title: In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, How to declare VAT on cash basis?
entry.content:
Dear
I wondered if somebody from your team could help us on an S4HANA public cloud finance question by pointing us in the right direction.

 

Our customer as 3 subsidiaries in Germany. They make VAT declaration on accrual.

Only 1 entity in Germany wants to make VAT declaration on cash.

 

Is this possible?

 

We are looking for a functionality which would generate VAT report in Germany based on payments. It should be called VAT on cash basis method, when you report your tax only in case it was already paid.

 

So the obligation to report VAT is further determined by the fact we have a payment in system related to invoice or other transaction where tax was posted.

 

It is an opposite to accrual VAT method, where tax must be reported immediately upon invoice posting regardless of its payment.

Thank you in advance.
Best regards,

entry.title: Re: ​A Step-by-Step Guide to Build a Custom Mobile Apps for Warehouse Management Using SAP Build Cod
entry.content:
@daidddd Thanks for sharing your experience building an MDK app in SAP Build.

I am curious why did you choose REST option in generating MDK UI step?

As the Warehouse Order and Task (WOT) is an OData service, I would recommend using the OData option instead of REST.
You can also enable offline functionalities in your app, if needed. Template itself will generate a fully working app with screens connecting to dataset e.g., WarehouseTask. You can always tweak the generated definitions according to your requirement.

entry.title: Java POJOs from cXML DTD
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

following "cXML Solutions Guide" (https://help.sap.com/docs/business-network-for-supply-chain/cxml-solutions/cxml-solutions-guide?locale=en-US) I want my application to exchange Purchase Orders with Ariba. My simple approach would be as following:

  1. download latest cXML DTD(s) from cxml.org
  2. generate source code for POJOs from DTD(s)
  3. in my application use Jackson (https://github.com/FasterXML/Jackson) to generate XML from Java objects
  4. receive response and - again - use Jackson to fill Java objects with information from XML


My questions:

- I used IntelliJ Ultimate to convert DTD to XSD. And I used jaxb2-maven-plugin from MojoHaus (former CodeHaus) to generated Java source code. Turns out that there are a lot of issues in the XSD. Am I using the right tools?

- are there somewhere cXML XSDs without issues?

- is the source code already available for this? (assuming that SAP VDM cannot be used)

- am I overthinking the whole thing and there is another easier, simpler way?

 

Thanks in advance,

- Daniel

entry.title: 🚀 Mastering SAP Cloud ALM – Change Management with a Demo Tenant: Your Step-by-Step Getting Started
entry.content:
SAP Cloud ALM (Application Lifecycle Management) is a modern, cloud-native platform developed by SAP to support the entire application lifecycle—from initial implementation and project planning to operations and continuous improvement. It’s designed for both cloud and hybrid environments, empowering businesses to gain visibility, control, and agility in managing their SAP landscapes.

In this comprehensive walkthrough, we’ll guide you through the practical setup and usage of SAP Cloud ALM using a demo tenant. Whether you’re an SAP Basis consultant, implementation lead, or project manager, this tutorial is tailored to help you understand core elements like Implementation Projects, System Groups, Features, Transport Management, and Deployment Planning.

https://support.sap.com/en/alm/demo-systems/cloud-alm-demo-system.html?anchorId=section_1043771746

 

 

 

👨‍💻 For this demo, we’ll be using the user Adam in the Cloud ALM tenant.

 

 

 

🧭 Step 1: Navigating to the Implementation App

To begin, access the “Implementation” tab from the main SAP Cloud ALM dashboard.

 

 

 

🔗 Navigate to: Implementation → Projects and Setup

 

 

🛠️ Step 2: Create and Configure Your Implementation Project

👉 In the “Projects and Setup” section, click on “Create Project”.
Provide a project name, a brief description, and select the appropriate product (e.g., SAP S/4HANA).

This setup enables structured tracking of implementation activities and aligns your technical tasks with business goals.

 

 

 

 

🧩 Step 3: Assign System Landscapes Using System Groups

➡️ Go to the System Groups section.
📌 Enter a name for your group and select the relevant SAP product (e.g., SAP S/4HANA).
Assign each system (Development, Quality, and Production) to its respective role.

 

 

 

 

 

💡 System Groups help ensure a smooth flow of transports across your SAP landscape by logically organizing system roles.

📦 Step 4: Define a Deployment Plan

Navigate to the Deployment Plan area.

🗂 Create a new deployment plan, associate it with your System Group, and specify relevant Release Versions.
This configuration allows you to coordinate when and how different features will be delivered across environments.

 

 

✔️ Once done, assign this plan to your implementation project.

 

 

🌟 Step 5: Manage Features and Functional Enhancements

Open the Features tab and click “Create Feature.”

 

 

A Feature in Cloud ALM is a unit of work or change. You can:

  • 🔗 Link it to a Requirement (business need).

 

  • 📦 Attach a Release to group multiple features into one go-live bundle.

 

  • 🧭 Align it with the Deployment Plan for controlled rollout.

📌 Features track the end-to-end journey of a change—from planning to productive use.

📤 Step 6: Assign or Create Transports for the Feature

Inside the feature, scroll to the Transports create section.

🛠 Click “Create Transport” to initiate a transport request.

 

 

 

 

Once assigned, click “Start Implementation” to activate development.

 

 


The feature status updates to “In Implementation.”

🔁 Step 7: Release Transport Tasks and Generate TOCs

When development is complete, release the individual tasks within the transport in the Development system.

 

🌀 Return to the Cloud ALM interface and click the “Copy” button in the Transports section to create a Transport of Copies (TOC).

 

 

✅ TOCs allow early testing of changes in the Quality system without releasing the main transport prematurely.

  • A grey icon indicates TOC creation is in progress.

 

 

  • Once successful, the icon turns green, and the TOC is auto-scheduled for import to Quality.

 

🧪 Step 8: Initiate Testing in Quality System

After successful import of the TOC into Quality:

🧪 Click “Handover to Test” within the feature.
The status will change to “In Testing”, signaling readiness for validation.

 

 

 

🚀 Step 9: Release and Deploy the Main Transport

Once changes are validated:

  1. Click “Release” to release the main TR from Development.

 

 

 

  1. Click “Deploy” to move the main TR into the Quality system.

 

🔄 This approach ensures compliance with change management best practices.

🏁 Step 10: Approve and Move to Production

After testing in Quality is complete:

  1. Update the feature status to “Approve for Production.”
  2.  

 

 

  1. It will now reflect as “Ready for Production.”

 

  1. Click “Deploy” again to move the main transport into the Production system.

 

📋 Use the History tab to review changes, user activity, and timestamps for full traceability.

 

 

✅ Conclusion

SAP Cloud ALM, when used via the demo tenant, provides a powerful sandbox environment to understand how lifecycle operations, project structures, and transport workflows are orchestrated in SAP.

By following this structured approach, you gain practical experience in:

  • Creating projects and system landscapes
  • Managing features and requirements
  • Orchestrating transport flows from Development to Production
  • Ensuring auditability and traceability with built-in monitoring

🎯 Whether you're preparing for a live customer implementation or upskilling on SAP Cloud ALM, this guide gives you a clear head start.

entry.title: Re: historial stocks and production orders are not visibl...
entry.content:
Go to transaction CFC2 in your ECC system.
Debug setting "R Debugging on and T/QRFCs are only recorded" can be useful for testing. Maintain the Debug setting "R" temporary during a test phase.
As soon as you have finished the tests, use "Debugging off" and change the Debug setting to " " (blank space) as shown in the options menu for this field.

entry.title: Re: Process modelling in SAP Signavio by importing proces...
entry.content:
Hi Gokul,
thanks for reaching out! SAP Signavio Process Manager offers BPMN import capabilities based on the BPMN 2.0 XML standard via UI or API. You can import BPMN files from external solutions if the export matches the BPMN notation:

  • SAP Help documentation for Importing a BPMN 2.0 XML
  • API
    • SAP Business Accelerator Hub
    • API Guide

Best regards
Manuel

entry.title: Re: Performance DB SELECT * FOR ALL statement can be joined with SELECT statement at ... line ...
entry.content:
I faced similar issue while using FOR ALL ENTRIES statement. I was able to remove the CHECK Message by adding SORT statement after the SELECT statement.

SELECT old_vendor FROM zxxx_vendor_xxx INTO TABLE gt_pur_lfa1 
FOR ALL ENTRIES IN gt_ekorg WHERE old_vendor = gt_ekorg-lifnr.
IF sy-subrc = 0.
  SORT gt_pur_lfa1 BY old_vendor.
ENDIF.

entry.title: Error Message Job Board Agentur für Arbeit
entry.content:
Hi,

our client is using the jobboard Agentur für Arbeit through Recruiting Posting. Since a recent update by Agentur für Arbeit, we see an error in the error logs of the job board. This error is not visible in RPO, only at Agentur für Arbeit's site:

 

<ErrorCode>FLR_JCValid_227</ErrorCode>
<AdditionalInformation>Bei Stellenangeboten vom Typ „Arbeit“ (JobOfferType = 1) ist die Form der Vergütungsangabe (CompensationProfile) erforderlich.</AdditionalInformation>
 

To me it looks like the problem is that the mandatory field "Form der Vergütungsangabe" is not filled. This is a field from the jobboard, but it is not available in Recruiting Posting, so we can neither map it to any JRDM field nor fill it in manually.

 

Has anyone else this problem? Or does anyone have an idea how the error can be solved?

 

Many thanks, Judith

entry.title: Identity and Access Management in SAP: Navigating SSO Across Web and On-Prem Landscapes
entry.content:
As explained in my latest post, managing Identity and Access Management (IAM) in SAP environments  is more crucial than ever. Beyond simply improving user experience, effective IAM ensures secure and consistent authentication mechanisms across both cloud and on-premise systems. At the heart of this strategy lies SAP Cloud Identity Services (SCI)—the go-to solution for centralized identity management and streamlined Single Sign-On (SSO) in the SAP ecosystem.

SCI serves as the central interface for managing identity and access across SAP solutions. It plays a foundational role in enabling SSO while enforcing authentication policies uniformly across the landscape. Within the Secure Operations Map (SOM), SSO is positioned squarely in the "Authentication and Single Sign-On" domain, underlining its critical role in maintaining secure and reliable access throughout your SAP systems.

Authentication in the Context of the Secure Operations Map (SOM)

One Authentication Experience Across Web and On-Premise

A key advantage of SCI is its ability to support both cloud-based and on-premise authentication scenarios. For browser-based applications, SCI supports modern protocols such as SAML 2.0 and OpenID Connect (OIDC). These standards are widely adopted across the SAP ecosystem and allow organizations to integrate with various identity providers while benefiting from centralized policy enforcement. For those navigating protocol choices, you can explore the comparison further in this blog post.

When it comes to authentication to on-premise applications, things work differently. These clients communicate via Remote Function Calls (RFC) rather than HTTP, which means traditional SAML or OIDC-based SSO methods don’t apply. To extend SSO capabilities here, SAP recommends using Secure Login Client in combination with Secure Login Service (SLS). This setup leverages short-lived X.509 certificates that are issued based on SCI-authenticated identities. The benefit of this approach is that it allows organizations to reuse the same Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) mechanisms you’ve implemented for web applications, ensuring a seamless and secure user experience across all access channels.

Single sign-on based on X.509 certificates – Process flow

There are other options than using short lived certificates via SLS available as well. Organizations can opt for Kerberos tokens, which are especially suitable for Windows-based environments, or deploy local short-lived client certificates.

For those seeking a more technical view of how these components interact, SAP offers a reference architecture for authentication, including SCI’s integration with both cloud and on-premise systems.

Authentication Reference Architecture

What’s Next: From Access Risks to Business Risks

With the fundamentals of access management and SSO in place, the next step is to examine broader business risks in your SAP landscape. In upcoming posts, we’ll shift focus to how these risks can be identified, analyzed, and contained using SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM)—a critical layer of protection beyond technical access controls.

entry.title: Cannot Perform MIGO After Changing and Restoring PO Release Strategy
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

I need help with an issue we're facing after changing our Purchase Order (PO) release strategy.

Initial Setup (Before Change):

We had several release strategy levels based on PO value:

A1: < 50 million → Approvers: 1A, 10

A2: > 50 million < 1 billion → Approvers: 1A, 10, 1B

A3: >  1 billion → Approvers: 1A, 10, 1B, 1C

We changed the release strategy to simplify it:

A1: ≥ 0 → Approvers: 1A, 10

After making this change, existing POs that were not yet released could not proceed because their original release strategy (e.g. A3) no longer existed.

So, I restored the A3 release strategy,  like before. Now, the PO can be released again, but when trying to do MIGO, we get the following error:

No goods receipt possible for purchase order 4010002627
Message no. M7036

We’ve verified that:

The PO exists

The items are not deleted or blocked

There are no confirmation controls active

The PO has been released

Questions:

What should I do to running well MIGO with that PO number?
What is the best practice when modifying or simplifying release strategies with existing open POs?
Thank you in advance!

entry.title: Re: Cannot Perform MIGO After Changing and Restoring PO R...
entry.content:
Here are common causes and what to check:

  • In ME23N, check the item-level “Goods Receipt” indicator under the Delivery tab. It must be ticked.
  • Some PO types may restrict GR. Confirm that the document type allows GR.
  • Ensure the material is extended to the plant/storage location and is allowed for GR.
  • If the delivery date is in the past or future beyond tolerance, GR may be blocked.
  • Check if the stock type (e.g., quality inspection) is causing issues.
  • Even if not active, double-check that it’s blank or not enforcing confirmations.

If all of the above checks out, try debugging MIGO to see if the system is still referencing the old release strategy classification. Sometimes, a PO created under a now-deleted strategy retains internal flags that block GR—even after restoration.

Also, check SAP notes 598342, 3335067 and  2291999
